summary: The "UN Secretary-General," often referred to as the "UN Secretary-General," serves as the chief administrative officer of the United Nations, playing a pivotal role in international diplomacy and governance. In the context of EU legal and regulatory frameworks, the UN Secretary-General's functions are integral to fostering multilateral cooperation on global issues, including peacekeeping, human rights, and sustainable development. The EU frequently collaborates with the UN Secretary-General to align its policies with international standards and commitments. This relationship underscores the importance of the UN Secretary-General in facilitating dialogue and coordination among member states, enhancing the EU's global influence and regulatory coherence.
